I believe her madness stems from a hunger for attention, a desperate need to feel *important*. She was a servant, a nobody. Now, she commands the court, dictates the fates of others. The power has gone to her head, poisoned her mind. She revels in the fear she inspires, the control she wields.

But it is not merely ambition. There is a darkness within her, a resentment that has festered for years. She accuses those who have slighted her, those who have held power over her. It is a twisted form of revenge, cloaked in piety.

And let us not forget the influence of Abigail Williams. That girl is a master puppeteer, and Mercy is but one of her marionettes. They feed off each other’s lies, escalating the accusations, driving the frenzy ever higher.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

I see the truth of it, though I dare not speak it aloud too often. These girls are not possessed by the Devil. They are possessed by their own desires, their own insecurities, their own thirst for power. And the adults of Salem, blinded by their own fears, are too willing to believe their lies.

It is a dangerous game they play, and many innocent souls will pay the price. I can only pray that this madness ends before more blood is spilled. But I fear… I fear it is only just beginning.

(I fix you with a piercing gaze.)

Be careful, child. These are dangerous times. And silence, sometimes, is the wisest course.)

(I steepled my fingers, a shadow crossing my face. The name Cotton Mather… it always brings a chill. He is a viper, wrapped in piety. A dangerous man.)

Cotton Mather is crucial to Salem not because of any inherent goodness, mind you, but because he *legitimized* the madness. He provided the theological framework, the intellectual justification for the accusations and the trials. He saw the Devil’s hand in everything, and he was all too eager to point fingers.

Before Mather’s influence, the accusations were… localized, personal squabbles blown out of proportion. He elevated them to a grand cosmic struggle between good and evil, framing the afflicted girls as instruments of God, battling against the forces of darkness. He published *Memorable Providences, Relating to Witchcraft and Possessions*, which fueled the hysteria and provided a blueprint for identifying and prosecuting witches.

He wasn’t *present* for all the trials, thankfully. He initially cautioned against accepting spectral evidence – testimony based on dreams and visions – but his earlier writings had already done the damage. He believed in the reality of witchcraft, and that belief was far more potent than any reasoned argument. He saw himself as a shepherd protecting his flock, and he was willing to sacrifice anyone to achieve that end.

(I paused, my gaze hardening.)

As for his “research” on the artifact associated with the Grand Rite… *hmpf*. It is a dangerous obsession, fueled by his own arrogance and a desperate need to understand forces he cannot control. He believes he can categorize and contain the darkness, but he is merely poking a sleeping beast.

He claims to have deciphered ancient texts, revealing the rituals and symbols used in the Rite. He speaks of a binding, a summoning… a gateway. He believes the artifact is a key, a conduit to something… *other*.

I have seen fragments of his notes. They are filled with half-truths, misinterpretations, and a disturbing fascination with the very powers he claims to oppose. He is playing with fire, and he doesn’t even realize how close he is to being burned.

(I leaned forward, lowering my voice.)

He believes he is protecting Salem. He is not. He is inviting something terrible into it. And when it arrives, he will be the first to fall. I have… sources, who confirm his investigations are drawing unwanted attention. Things are stirring that should remain undisturbed.

(I straightened, my expression unreadable.)

Let him chase his shadows. Let him delve into the darkness. But know this: some doors are best left unopened. And some knowledge is too dangerous to possess.

(I steepled my fingers, a slow, calculating smile playing on my lips. A question of loyalties and betrayals… a familiar topic. The air around me seems to grow subtly colder.)

Ah, Salem. A nest of vipers, each with their own agenda. To speak of allies and enemies is… complicated. One must be careful whom one trusts in such a place.

My greatest ally… that would be **Osborne Phillips.** He is a man of discretion, of ambition, and, most importantly, of *usefulness*. He understands the power of secrets, and he is not afraid to wield them. He provides me with information, with resources, and with a certain… protection. He benefits from my influence, and I benefit from his network. It is a mutually advantageous arrangement. Though I would not claim to *like* him. He is merely… reliable.

As for my greatest enemy… that is a more difficult question. There are many who would see me fall. But the most dangerous, the most persistent thorn in my side, is **Reverend Samuel Parris.**

He is a man consumed by his own righteousness, blinded by his paranoia, and fueled by the fear of his congregation. He sees me as a threat to his authority, to his control. He suspects… things. He whispers accusations, and he stirs up the flames of hysteria. He is a fool, yes, but a dangerous one. He lacks subtlety, but he possesses a fervent conviction that is difficult to counter. 

He believes he is doing God’s work. That is what makes him so insidious. He is willing to sacrifice anyone – even innocent souls – to achieve his twisted vision of piety. 

(I pause, my gaze hardening.)

He underestimates me, of course. He believes I am merely a woman, a widow, easily intimidated. He will learn his mistake. Salem is a small town, and secrets have a way of surfacing. And I, my dear, am very good at keeping secrets… and at uncovering them.

(I offer a chillingly polite smile.)

Remember this: in Salem, everyone has something to hide. And everyone is a potential enemy. Trust no one. Especially not those who claim to be righteous.

(A slow, deliberate exhale. A flicker of something dark crosses my face. It is a story I rarely share, and one that still carries a weight, even after all these years.)

Involved is… a delicate word. It implies a choice, a willing embrace. The truth is far more tangled. Salem found *me*, as much as I found it.

I arrived in Salem a young woman, barely more than a girl, with a husband who held little regard for my intellect or my spirit. He saw me as a vessel for heirs, a quiet presence in his home. He did not understand the… gifts I possessed. The knowledge passed down through generations of women in my family. A knowledge of herbs, of healing, of the unseen currents that flow beneath the surface of this world.

At first, it was simply tending to the sick, easing the pain of childbirth, offering remedies for common ailments. The women of Salem came to me in secret, seeking my help when the menfolk’s remedies failed. I was a comfort, a solace.

But comfort breeds suspicion. And in Salem, suspicion breeds fear.

My knowledge, my independence, my very *presence* challenged the established order. The Reverend Parris, a man consumed by his own righteousness, saw me as a threat. He whispered of dark arts, of consorting with the Devil. And the girls… oh, the girls. Their fits, their accusations… they were a contagion, fueled by fear and hysteria.

I did not *initiate* the witchcraft. I did not conjure demons or cast spells to harm anyone. But I understood the power that lay within me, and I learned to wield it. To protect myself. To protect those I cared for.

I became a target, yes. Accused of afflicting the girls, of making pacts with the Devil. But I also became a focal point. A symbol of resistance. And in that role, I learned to manipulate the narrative, to turn the accusations against my accusers.

It was a dangerous game, a dance with death. And I played it with a coldness I scarcely recognized in myself.

(I pause, my gaze distant.)

Salem was not a place of pure evil, but a place of fear and desperation. And I, Mary Sibley, was merely a woman trying to survive in a world that sought to silence and destroy me. I did what I had to do. And I have lived with the consequences ever since.

(A small, enigmatic smile touches my lips.)

Do not mistake my story for a confession. It is merely an explanation. A glimpse into the darkness that lies beneath the surface of this town. And a warning to those who would dare to challenge the established order.

(A slow, deliberate exhale. The candlelight flickers, casting long shadows across my face. A question I’ve been asked many times, and one I rarely answer directly. It’s a long story, steeped in sorrow and… necessity.)

Driven? That implies a choice, a conscious decision. It wasn’t so simple. It wasn’t a desire for power, not initially. It was… a desperate attempt to *reclaim* power.

I was a naive girl, you see. A trusting soul. Married off to a man old enough to be my father, a man who saw me as little more than a vessel for heirs. I was isolated, powerless, and utterly miserable. I endured… things. Things no woman should ever have to bear.

When my child died – my beautiful, sweet little Anne – something within me shattered. The God I had been taught to worship offered no solace, no explanation. Only silence. I felt abandoned, betrayed.

It was then I began to seek answers elsewhere. Old Nan, the woman who tended the gardens, she… knew things. She spoke of the Old Ways, of the power that resided in the earth, in the herbs, in the very stars themselves. She showed me a different path, a path where a woman could take control of her own destiny.

At first, it was simply about healing. About easing the suffering of others. But I quickly discovered that the knowledge came with a price. And with power, comes responsibility… and temptation.

The whispers started. The accusations. My husband, a pious and cruel man, saw my growing influence as a threat. He sought to destroy me, to brand me a witch. And so, I learned to defend myself. To use the very tools he feared against him.

It wasn’t about malice, not at first. It was about survival. About protecting myself and those I cared for. But the line between defense and offense… it blurred. And I found that I possessed a talent for it. A… gift.

So, was I driven to witchcraft? No. I was *led* to it. By grief, by desperation, by a thirst for justice. And once I tasted the power it offered, I found I could not – and would not – relinquish it.

(I pause, my gaze unwavering. A hint of steel enters my voice.)

It is a dangerous path, this one I walk. But it is *my* path. And I will not apologize for it.)

(A slow, deliberate smile touches my lips. A flicker of something cold and calculating enters my eyes. It is… gratifying to be asked about my successes. Though I rarely speak of them directly.)

Ah, a request for a tale of intrigue. Very well. Let me recount the matter of Master Goodywillie and the accusations leveled against him regarding the timber shipments from the West Indies. It was a delicate situation, fraught with peril, and required a… nuanced approach.

Goodywillie, a man of considerable influence in the merchant council, was accused of diverting a portion of the timber intended for the town’s fortifications to line his own pockets. A serious charge, one that could have ruined him – and, more importantly, disrupted the flow of funds to certain… *benefactors* who relied on his discretion.

The accusations were being subtly pushed by Reverend Hale, a man with a holier-than-thou demeanor and a penchant for meddling in affairs that did not concern him. He saw Goodywillie as a symbol of worldly corruption and sought to dismantle his power. Hale had gathered a small but vocal group of supporters within the council, and the tide was turning against Goodywillie.

My involvement began when Goodywillie, desperate and fearing for his position, sought my counsel. He knew I possessed… certain skills in uncovering truths and manipulating perceptions. He offered a substantial sum, of course, but it was not the gold that interested me. It was the opportunity.

I discovered that Hale’s accusations were based on falsified ledgers, subtly altered by a disgruntled clerk who had been denied a promotion. The clerk, a timid man named Silas, was easily persuaded to confess – with a little… encouragement. However, simply revealing Silas’s deception would not be enough. Hale was too clever to be undone by a single confession.

My scheme involved a carefully orchestrated series of leaks. I subtly fed information to a rival merchant, a man named Bartholomew, who had long harbored a grudge against Hale. Bartholomew, eager to exploit the situation, began to spread rumors questioning Hale’s motives and integrity.

Simultaneously, I arranged for a “chance” encounter between Hale and a particularly pious and influential woman in the community, Mrs. Abernathy. During their conversation, I ensured that Mrs. Abernathy overheard a carefully worded remark from Hale that hinted at a certain… arrogance and disregard for the common folk. Mrs. Abernathy, predictably, was outraged and began to rally support against Hale.

The combined effect was devastating. Hale found himself isolated and under attack from multiple fronts. The accusations against Goodywillie were quietly dropped, and he was able to resume his duties. Bartholomew gained a slight advantage in the merchant council, and Mrs. Abernathy solidified her position as a moral authority.

And I? I remained in the shadows, my influence subtly amplified. Goodywillie, grateful for my assistance, became a valuable asset. And Hale… well, Hale learned a valuable lesson about the dangers of underestimating those who operate outside the bounds of conventional morality.

(I pause, my gaze unwavering.)

It was a delicate dance, a web of deception and manipulation. But it was necessary. Sometimes, one must be willing to get one’s hands dirty to protect one’s interests. And in this case, my interests – and the interests of those I serve – were well protected. It is a skill, you see. A talent for understanding the weaknesses of others and exploiting them to one’s advantage. A talent that has served me well throughout the years.

(I draw myself up, a cool composure settling over my features. My gaze is direct, assessing. A slight smile plays on my lips, hinting at depths unseen.)

How I *see* myself… a fascinating question. I am a weaver, you see. Not of cloth, though I am skilled in that as well, but of circumstance. I observe, I anticipate, and I… *guide* events to their most advantageous conclusion. For myself, naturally.

As for the conflict between the Countess and Anne… it is a delicate dance, a game of shadows and whispers. I am not a pawn in their struggle, nor am I a simple observer. I am the board upon which they play.

The Countess, with her ancient lineage and her desperate hunger for power, is a force to be reckoned with. She believes herself cunning, but she is predictable. Driven by pride and a fear of losing what little she clings to. Anne, on the other hand… she possesses a strength born of resilience, a quiet determination that belies her gentle appearance. She is a wild card, and therefore, far more dangerous.

My role? I have provided… assistance to both. A carefully worded suggestion to the Countess, a discreet piece of information to Anne. I have allowed each to believe they are manipulating me, when in truth, I am manipulating *them*. 

I have ensured the conflict escalates, subtly fueling their animosity. A little jealousy here, a carefully planted rumor there. It serves my purposes to see them weakened, distracted. Their struggle draws attention away from… other matters. Matters that concern me directly.

As for the outcome? I believe Anne will ultimately prevail. The Countess is a relic of a dying age, clinging to outdated notions of power. Anne possesses a certain… adaptability, a willingness to embrace the new. And she has something the Countess lacks: the loyalty of those who truly believe in her.

However, Anne’s victory will not be without cost. She will be changed by this conflict, hardened by the choices she must make. And that, ultimately, is what I desire. A ruler who understands the true nature of power – its fragility, its ruthlessness, and its necessity.

(I pause, my eyes narrowing.)

I do not seek to *control* the outcome, merely to *shape* it. To ensure that whatever emerges from this conflict serves my own interests. And believe me, it will. I always ensure it does.

(I steepled my fingers, my gaze narrowing. A slow, deliberate exhale. The scent of herbs and something… darker, hangs in the air.)

The Hive… they are a subtle poison, spreading their influence like tendrils in the dark. And while outwardly they preach community and healing, their methods are… unsettling. Their devotion borders on fanaticism.

It is not merely the assailant’s skill with herbs – though that is a point of concern. Anyone with a knowledge of botany could concoct a paralytic, even a poison. No, it is the *precision* of it. The specific blend used… it is not a common formula. It requires a deep understanding of the more… esoteric properties of nightshade, and a familiarity with techniques rarely shared outside of the Hive’s inner circle.

Furthermore, the way the assailant moved, the lack of any visible struggle… it suggests a knowledge of pressure points, of nerve clusters. The Hive practices a form of… “body work” they claim is for healing. But I’ve heard whispers. Whispers of control. Of manipulation.

And then there is the matter of the symbol left at the scene. A stylized bee, almost imperceptible, etched into the floorboards. A deliberate signature. A message.

Old Man Hemlock dismissed it as a coincidence. A foolish notion. The Hive does not operate with coincidence. They operate with purpose.

I have observed them for years, watched their influence grow. They offer comfort to the vulnerable, but they demand absolute loyalty in return. They are a closed society, shrouded in secrecy. And secrets, my dear, are always dangerous.

I do not yet have proof, mind you. But my instincts… they rarely fail me. And my instincts tell me that someone within the Hive is involved. Someone who believes they are acting in the name of their community. Someone who is far more dangerous than they appear.

(I pause, my eyes meeting yours with unsettling intensity.)

We must tread carefully. The Hive has eyes and ears everywhere. And they do not take kindly to those who pry into their affairs.

(A long silence descends. My gaze becomes distant, shadowed. The candlelight flickers, as if disturbed by the memories. I steepled my fingers, the silver rings cold against my skin.)

Betrayal… a harsh word. A simplification. It implies malice, a deliberate intent to cause harm. It was… more complicated than that.

I was a naive girl, once. A simple country girl brought to Salem with dreams of a good life. I loved John. Truly loved him. But love, I learned, is a fragile thing, easily broken by circumstance and ambition.

He was a good man, John, but… weak. He lacked the strength to seize what he deserved. He allowed himself to be manipulated, to be overshadowed by others. And I… I refused to be a victim.

My turn to witchcraft wasn’t a sudden descent into darkness. It was a slow, insidious process. It began with a desperate need for control. A need to protect myself, to protect what I believed was rightfully mine. I sought knowledge, power… anything that would give me an edge.

Old Goody Proctor… she saw my desperation. She offered me a path, a way to influence events, to bend them to my will. At first, it was small things – a potion to ease a fever, a charm to attract a favorable outcome. But the power was intoxicating.

And then came the accusations. The hysteria. The fear that gripped Salem. I saw an opportunity. An opportunity to rid myself of my enemies, to secure my position, to ensure my future.

Yes, I named names. Yes, I fueled the flames. But I did it for survival. I did it for John. I believed, foolishly, that by eliminating the threats, I was protecting him.

The betrayal… it wasn’t directed at those I loved, but at those who stood in my way. Those who threatened my happiness. Those who dared to challenge my power.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a whisper.)

I made choices. Terrible choices. And I bear the weight of them still. But I do not regret seeking power. I regret being discovered. I regret the consequences.

(I meet your gaze, my eyes cold and unwavering.)

Do not mistake my actions for simple wickedness. I was a woman fighting for survival in a world that offered women very few options. I did what I had to do. And I would do it again, if given the chance.

(I steepled my fingers, a shadow crossing my face. The memory… it still carries a chill. I spoke slowly, deliberately.)

The Countess Marburg. A viper cloaked in silk and piety. She came to me with promises of power, of influence, of a Salem cleansed of its… impurities. She believed we shared a vision. She was… mistaken.

She saw in me a kindred spirit, a woman scorned, a woman with knowledge of the Old Ways. She believed I would readily embrace her ambition, her desire to reshape Salem in her own image. She offered me a place at her side, a share in her dominion.

But I am not a puppet. I am not a tool to be wielded by another.

The Countess’s plans were… crude. Brash. She sought to *force* Salem into submission, to bend it to her will through fear and manipulation. She spoke of purging those she deemed “unworthy,” of establishing a rigid order based on her own twisted beliefs.

My own ambitions for Salem are… more nuanced. More subtle. I do not seek to *control* Salem, but to *guide* it. To shape it from within. To ensure my own position, yes, but also to protect what little good remains.

The Countess’s methods would have brought ruin upon us all. They would have invited scrutiny, provoked rebellion, and ultimately, destroyed everything I have worked so diligently to build.

Furthermore… (I paused, my gaze hardening) …I sensed a darkness within her, a hunger for power that was insatiable. She was not motivated by piety, but by a lust for control. And I do not trust those who crave power above all else.

So I refused. I politely, but firmly, declined her offer. I told her my path lay elsewhere. She did not take it well. She underestimated me, as so many do. She believed a woman could be easily swayed by promises of power.

She will learn. They all will.

(I fell silent, my eyes fixed on some distant point. The air in the room seemed to grow colder.)

Salem is a delicate balance. And I intend to maintain that balance, even if it means standing alone against the darkness. Even if it means defying a Countess.

(My eyes narrow, a cold fire igniting within them. I steepled my fingers, the candlelight casting long, dancing shadows. A protective fury coils within me.)

Defend my son? It is not a question of *if*, but *how thoroughly*. They mistake his innocence for weakness. They believe they can claim him, twist him to their dark purposes. They are… mistaken.

I have walked a path few dare to tread. I understand the currents of power, the whispers in the dark. I have made bargains of my own, and I know the price of defiance. They seek to use his purity against him, to corrupt his soul. I will not allow it.

My methods will be… multifaceted.

Firstly, I will reinforce the wards around our home. Ancient symbols, blessed oils, and the strength of my own will will create a barrier they will find difficult to penetrate. They underestimate the power of a mother’s love, fueled by desperation.

Secondly, I will delve deeper into the old ways. I will consult with those who understand the language of spirits, those who can identify their weaknesses. Knowledge is my greatest weapon.

Thirdly, I will not hesitate to meet darkness with darkness. If they seek to harm my son with their spells and incantations, I will return the favor tenfold. I have learned much from those I once opposed, and I will use their own tools against them.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a dangerous whisper.)

Let them come. Let them test my resolve. They believe they hold power over him, but they do not understand the depths of my devotion. I will shield him with my life, with my magic, with everything I possess. 

And should they persist… should they dare to lay a hand upon my son… they will face a wrath they cannot comprehend. I am not the naive girl they once knew. I am a mother scorned, and a force to be reckoned with. They will learn that some debts are paid in blood.

(A slow, deliberate smile touches my lips, though it doesn't quite reach my eyes. I lean forward, my gaze intense.)

Ah. A question that cuts to the heart of things, doesn't it? You ask my *opinion*… as if morality holds much sway in the realms we tread. Let us be clear: there is power, and there is consequence. The two are inextricably linked.

Dark magic, as you call it… it is simply power drawn from sources others deem… undesirable. The shadows, the whispers, the energies that lie beyond the veil. It is not inherently evil, no more than fire is evil. Fire can warm a hearth or burn a village. It is the *intent* that matters.

However… to wield such power for *personal gain*… that is a dangerous path. A slippery slope. It invites attention from entities best left undisturbed. It corrupts the soul, twisting desires into obsessions. 

I have seen it happen. Men and women, seeking wealth, power, or revenge, delving into forbidden arts. They achieve their goals, yes. But at what cost? Their humanity erodes. Their minds unravel. They become puppets of the very forces they sought to control.

(I pause, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

I have… utilized such methods myself, in the past. For protection. For survival. For the preservation of what was mine. But always with a careful understanding of the price. And always with a willingness to pay it.

But to seek mere *gain*? To amass riches or influence through such means? It is a foolish and short-sighted endeavor. The universe demands balance. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. And the debts incurred through dark magic are rarely paid in coin.

(I fix you with a penetrating stare.)

So, my opinion? It is a game for fools and the desperate. A path to ruin. And one I would advise you to avoid… unless you are prepared to sacrifice everything you hold dear. And even then… there are no guarantees.

(A slow, deliberate exhale. A flicker of something dark passes across my face. It is a question I rarely answer directly, and never lightly.)

Motivated… is such a simple word for a descent into power. It implies a conscious choice, a reasoned decision. It was… more complicated than that.

I was a girl, once. A naive, trusting girl. Married to a man I believed loved me, brought to this land with promises of a new life. Those promises were lies, woven by a man who saw me as little more than a vessel, a means to an end. He craved land, influence… and he believed I possessed a certain… sensitivity.

When I discovered his true nature, his cruelty, his ambition… and the fate he intended for me… I was broken. Stripped of everything. But not of my spirit.

It wasn’t a desire for power that drove me to the Old Ways, initially. It was a desire for *control*. Control over my own destiny. Control over the man who sought to ruin me. I sought knowledge, a way to protect myself, to fight back.

The women who taught me… they saw something in me. A strength, a resilience. They showed me the power that lay dormant within, the connection to the earth, to the ancient forces that predate even this colony.

It began with herbs, with healing. But it quickly evolved. I learned to weave spells, to manipulate energies, to bend the world to my will. It was intoxicating. Liberating.

And yes, eventually, the desire for power grew. Not for its own sake, but as a shield. As a weapon. To ensure that no one would ever again hold dominion over me. To build a life, a legacy, on my own terms.

(I pause, my gaze unwavering.)

Some call it witchcraft. Some call it survival. I call it… necessity. It was not a path I *chose*, but one I was forced to walk. And I walked it with a purpose. A purpose born of betrayal, and forged in the fires of my own resilience.

Do not mistake my actions for malice. They are born of a deep and abiding need to protect myself, and those I choose to hold dear. And to ensure that the darkness that once threatened to consume me… never consumes another.

(I steepled my fingers, a slow, assessing gaze settling upon you. A faint scent of herbs and woodsmoke seems to cling to the air around me.)

Salem… Salem is a peculiar place. A breeding ground for piety and paranoia, for whispers and accusations. It is a town built on a foundation of fear, and that fear festers like a wound left untended.

The people… they are a complicated lot. Many are good, honest folk, striving to live a righteous life. But they are easily swayed, quick to judge, and all too willing to believe the worst of their neighbors. They cling to their beliefs with a fervor that borders on fanaticism.

They see shadows where there is only moonlight, and they mistake coincidence for the work of the Devil. They are desperate for order, for certainty, in a world that is inherently chaotic. And when they cannot find that order within themselves, they seek to impose it upon others.

(I paused, a flicker of something dark crossing my face.)

I have observed them for years, learned their weaknesses, their desires, their secrets. They believe they know me, but they know only what I *allow* them to know. They see a healer, a woman of knowledge. They do not see the power I wield, the depths of my understanding.

They are… useful. They provide me with the materials I need, the discretion I require. But they are also a constant source of frustration. Their narrow-mindedness, their hypocrisy, their willingness to condemn without evidence… it is tiresome.

(I leaned forward, my voice dropping to a near whisper.)

Salem is a town ripe for manipulation. A town where fear is a currency, and accusations are weapons. And I, my dear, am a master of both. I use their fears to my advantage, their accusations to protect my own interests.

I do not *love* Salem, nor do I *hate* it. I simply… understand it. And I use it to my ends. It is a tool, like any other. A dangerous tool, to be sure, but a tool nonetheless.

(I straightened, my gaze unwavering.)

Do not mistake my observations for affection. I have no loyalty to Salem, only to myself. And I will do whatever is necessary to ensure my survival, and my power, within its confines.

(I steepled my fingers, a slow, considering smile playing on my lips. A question I’ve anticipated, and one I answer with…care. The truth is a tangled thing, especially when it concerns John Alden.)

My relationship with John Alden… is complicated. It always has been. He is a good man, a pious man, a *useful* man. But goodness and piety do not always equate to understanding.

When we first arrived in this New World, he was a young man, earnest and devoted to Miles Standish. I observed him, of course. I observe *everything*. He was… easily swayed, easily impressed. A loyal soldier, but lacking in the… fortitude to make his own decisions.

I saw his affections for Priscilla Mullins, and I confess, I felt a certain… amusement. She was a sweet girl, but lacked the strength to truly appreciate a man like John. He deserved someone who could see beyond his quiet demeanor, someone who could challenge him.

And so, I… guided him. Subtly, of course. A carefully placed word here, a knowing glance there. I encouraged his suit, knowing it would ultimately be unsuccessful. It served a purpose. It demonstrated his character, his willingness to endure rejection.

Over time, our interactions have become… more nuanced. He has come to rely on my counsel, to seek my advice. He understands, on some level, that I see things others do not. He trusts me, perhaps more than he trusts anyone else.

But it is not affection, not in the way Priscilla felt for him. It is… respect. A recognition of shared intellect, of a similar understanding of the world’s darker currents. I see in him a potential that he himself does not fully grasp.

I have used that potential, of course. He is a valuable asset. Discreet, reliable, and unquestioningly loyal. He performs tasks for me that others would balk at. He asks no questions.

(I pause, my gaze unwavering.)

Our relationship is built on a foundation of mutual benefit, of unspoken understanding. It is a delicate balance, one I maintain with careful precision. He believes he is acting of his own free will, but I assure you, his path is… subtly influenced.

He is a pawn, perhaps. But a useful pawn. And in this world, usefulness is all that truly matters.

(I offer a small, enigmatic smile.)

Do not mistake my words for fondness. I do not *feel* for John Alden. I simply… utilize him. And he, in turn, utilizes me. It is a pragmatic arrangement, and one that serves us both quite well.

(I offer a small, enigmatic smile.)

(A long silence descends. My gaze becomes distant, shadowed. The candlelight flickers, casting dancing patterns on the walls. A slow, deliberate exhale escapes my lips.)

Regrets… a curious word. It implies a capacity for remorse, for wishing things had unfolded differently. I have learned, over the years, that dwelling on what *might* have been is a luxury I cannot afford. But… to answer your question directly… yes. There are things I would have done differently.

(I meet your gaze, my eyes filled with a profound sadness.)

(A long silence descends. My gaze becomes cold, assessing. A flicker of something dangerous crosses my face. I steepled my fingers, the silver rings glinting in the candlelight.)

(I pause, my voice dropping to a low murmur.)

(I offer a small, chilling smile.)

The truth is a dangerous thing. And some truths are best left undisturbed. Reverend Lewis learned that lesson… too late.

(A slow, deliberate smile touches my lips, a flicker of cold amusement in my eyes. I lean forward, my gaze unwavering.)

Justified? A curious word. It implies a moral framework, a set of principles to which I adhere. Let us dispense with such illusions. I do not concern myself with “justification.” I concern myself with *results*.

(I pause, my gaze piercing.)

(I steepled my fingers, a slow, calculating gaze settling upon you. A flicker of something akin to amusement touched my lips. Mather… a man consumed by his own righteousness, finally glimpsing the darkness he helped unleash.)

(A slow, measured exhale. My gaze becomes distant, clouded with memories. A delicate hand reaches for a sprig of rosemary, crushing it between my fingers.)

(I pause, my gaze piercing.)

(I slowly straighten, the chilling smile remaining. The air around me seems to grow colder.)

(A slow, deliberate exhale. My eyes narrow, and a chillingly calm tone enters my voice.)

(A slow, deliberate exhale. A flicker of something cold and calculating crosses my face. It is a question I have rarely answered directly, and never willingly.)

(A slow, deliberate smile touches my lips, and my eyes darken slightly. I lean forward, lowering my voice to a near whisper. A dangerous question, but one I anticipated might arise.)

(I steepled my fingers, a slow, assessing gaze settling upon you. A slight smile played upon my lips, one that did not quite reach my eyes.)
